Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD reasonably concluded the applicant failed to meet residency obligation under section 61(3) of IRPR
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR) s.61(3)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant worked in China for a Canadian company with minimal presence in Canada; employment not temporary, no intention to return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court upheld decision
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Federal Court dismissed judicial review, found IAD decision reasonable
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failed to maintain physical presence or demonstrate intent to return to Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Assignment outside Canada by Canadian business without fulfilling residency requirements
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to IAD's interpretation
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Temporary nature of foreign assignment and maintenance of ties to Canada
Crimes.Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), IRPR s.61(3)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal before IAD followed by judicial review in Federal Court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD found lack of genuine intent to return to work in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Employment records, duration of stay outside Canada, travel history
Crimes.Application_Basis: Claim of being temporarily assigned abroad by Canadian employer
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Work contracts, time spent in Canada vs. abroad, communication with employer
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reinstatement of permanent resident status or acceptance of residency compliance
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Section 61(3) IRPR – temporary assignment exception requires maintained connection to Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of temporary assignment and intent to resume work in Canada
Crimes.Outcome: Permanent residence card refused due to failure to meet residency obligation
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Loss of permanent resident status and associated rights
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicants did not meet minimum residency requirements over five-year period
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: IAD evaluated documentary evidence and credibility of claims
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Lack of corroborating evidence showing ongoing employment relationship and intent to return
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not met – insufficient days physically present or constructively credited
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD has authority to hear appeals on residency obligation matters
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Findings supported by record; no palpable and overriding error
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Employment abroad was de facto permanent, not temporary; no active role in Canadian operations
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to provide sufficient documentation proving temporary nature of assignment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate consideration refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Refusal of H&C Consideration Due to Residency Non-Compliance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD's refusal of humanitarian and compassionate grounds was reasonable
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.28
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants spent minimal time in Canada, lacked strong familial, economic, or social ties
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD denied H&C relief; Federal Court upheld denial
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review seeking reversal of IAD’s H&C refusal
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Federal Court dismissed application, affirmed reasonableness of IAD decision
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Prolonged absence from Canada without compelling reasons justifying non-compliance
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for exemption from residency obligation based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Strength of ties to Canada, best interests of any children, establishment in home country
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: H&C assessment conducted during appeal before IAD, followed by judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: H&C claims considered but outweighed by lack of effort to comply with obligations
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family connections, property ownership, community involvement, explanations for absence
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for exceptional relief due to personal circumstances despite non-compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Nature and depth of ties to Canada, sincerity of re-establishment intent
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Grant of permanent resident status based on H&C considerations
Crimes.Governing_Rule: IRPA s.28 allows discretion to consider H&C factors when residency obligation unmet
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited evidence of hardship or exceptional circumstances warranting relief
Crimes.Outcome: H&C request denied; no override of residency failure
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Denial of continued status and potential removal from Canada
Crimes.Cause_Description: Failure to meet residency obligations coupled with insufficient H&C justification
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: IAD balanced all factors, gave appropriate weight to compliance expectations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.28 – failure to satisfy conditions for H&C relief
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Generalized claims without concrete supporting documentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD has jurisdiction to assess H&C claims in residency appeals
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Decision based on holistic evaluation of applicant circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Absence of significant ties and weak H&C arguments do not justify waiver
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient proof of exceptional hardship or compelling reasons
